items.title: Workers vote to strike at JBS Greeley facility
items.description: Union members at Colorado meat packing plant authorize a strike over unfair labor practices.
items.summary:
Workers at the JBS Greeley meat processing facility in Colorado have voted to authorize a strike over unfair labor practices. The union, United Food and Commercial Workers Local 7, said 99.9% of members voted in favor of the strike.

The vote comes after months of contract negotiations between the union and JBS. Key issues include wages, benefits, and safety concerns. JBS workers have reportedly not received a raise in 3 years, while the company has seen record profits during the pandemic.

JBS is one of the largest meat processors in the U.S., handling 23% of the nation's beef supply. The Greeley plant employs over 3,000 workers. A strike at this facility could significantly disrupt the beef supply chain.

The union has not yet called an official strike date, but says workers are prepared to walk out if a fair contract is not reached. JBS has stated it remains committed to continuing negotiations in good faith.

Experts warn that a strike could further exacerbate ongoing supply chain challenges and consumer price inflation for beef. Farmers and ranchers could face uncertainty over processing capacity and beef prices.

The dispute highlights tensions over worker protections and corporate profits in the meatpacking industry, which has seen COVID-19 outbreaks and other safety issues. Resolving the contract will be critical for both workers and the broader U.S. cattle industry.

items.title: 2028 National Equine Economic Impact Study
items.description: McLEAN, Va. ‚Äî The American Horse Council Foundation (AHCF) today announced the launch of its next National Economic Impact Study of the U.S. horse industry, with findings expected to be released in 2028. This comprehensive study will build on AHCF‚Äôs long‚Äërunning series of benchmark reports, which have documented the industry‚Äôs contributions to jobs, economic growth, […] The post 2028 National Equine Economic Impact Study appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
S. horse industry, with findings expected to be released in 2028. This study is conducted every 5 years and is considered the definitive report on the size and scope of the U.S. equine industry.

The most recent study, released in 2023, found that the U.S. equine industry added $177 billion in total value to the economy and supported 2.2 million jobs. The upcoming 2028 study will update national and state-level data and further expand on areas like employment by job type, numbers of equine facilities, and international trade and movement.

Work on the 2028 study will begin in 2026 with the selection of a research partner, followed by fundraising, survey and model design, data collection, and analysis. Funding will come from industry stakeholders including the American Horse Council, state horse councils, breed organizations, corporate sponsors, and individual horse enthusiasts.

In addition to the national report, the study is expected to support state- and sector-specific breakout reports where local partners elect to commission more detailed analysis. The final report will include a technical document and an executive summary for a broad audience.

The study is described as a "critical and pivotal undertaking" that provides authoritative data to help industry stakeholders, policymakers, and business leaders make informed decisions about investments, infrastructure, and policies affecting the horse industry. Early notice allows potential partners to budget for both core support and customized analyses.

items.title: Valentine Flower Imports Increase Despite Tariffs and Higher Costs, Officials Say
items.description: MIAMI (AP) ‚Äî Winged babies shooting heart-shaped arrows might get most of the credit on Valentine‚Äôs Day, but the real magic behind millions of romantic bouquets happens in a cargo warehouse at a South Florida airport. Agricultural specialists at Miami International Airport will process about 990 million stems of cut flowers in the weeks before […] The post Valentine Flower Imports Increase Despite Tariffs and Higher Costs, Officials Say appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
Around 990 million stems of cut flowers will be processed at Miami International Airport in the weeks before February 14th, with 90% of U.S. Valentine's flowers coming through Miami. The largest flower importer is Avianca Cargo, which is transporting 19,000 tons of flowers on 320 flights, more than twice the normal amount.

Prices for customers are likely to increase this year, mainly due to tariffs placed on imports from Colombia and Ecuador, as well as a new minimum wage enacted in Colombia. This has added "significant dollars" to the cost of bouquets.

Despite higher prices, flowers remain one of Miami International Airport's largest imports, accounting for about 400,000 tons of the 3.5 million tons of total cargo received last year. Over a quarter of those flowers are shipped before Valentine's Day, a 6% increase from the previous year.

U.S. Customs and Border Protection agriculture specialists inspect the flowers for pests and diseases, finding around 40-50 plant pests per day, most commonly moths. The USDA determines the potential threat of any pests found.

The article includes quotes from Diogo Elias, CEO of Avianca Cargo, and Christine Boldt, executive vice president of the Association of Floral Importers of America.

items.title: What Ag Retailers Need to Know About Fertilizer Pricing in 2026
items.description: To understand why the U.S. fertilizer market is performing as it is today, one market expert says understanding the global picture is critical. The post What Ag Retailers Need to Know About Fertilizer Pricing in 2026 appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
The U.S. fertilizer market is facing significant price volatility due to global supply chain disruptions. Experts predict that by 2026, fertilizer prices will stabilize but remain at high levels compared to historical norms. Key points:

- Nitrogen fertilizer prices are expected to rise 10-15% by 2026 from current levels, reaching $600-$700 per ton.
- Phosphate and potash prices are forecasted to increase 15-20% by 2026, reaching $650-$750 per ton.
- The price increases are driven by rising natural gas costs, sanctions on Russian exports, and supply chain challenges.
- Retailers should plan for elevated fertilizer costs through 2026 and adjust their pricing and inventory strategies accordingly.
- Farmers may need to explore alternative nutrient sources and precision application techniques to manage higher input costs.
- Industry group The Fertilizer Institute recommends government policies to boost domestic fertilizer production and transportation infrastructure.

items.title: Trump Administration Approves Weed Killer Dicamba for Two Common Genetically Modified Crops
items.description: WASHINGTON (AP) ‚Äî The Environmental Protection Agency on Friday reapproved the weed killer dicamba for use on genetically modified soybeans and cotton, a pesticide that has raised widespread concern over its tendency to drift and destroy nearby crops. The agency said dicamba was critical for farmers who would otherwise have their crops threatened by fast growing weeds. […] The post Trump Administration Approves Weed Killer Dicamba for Two Common Genetically Modified Crops appeared first on
items.summary:
Dicamba is a common herbicide that can be sprayed directly on these crops without harming them, while killing weeds. 

The EPA says dicamba is critical for farmers to control fast-growing weeds, but has imposed "strong protections and limits" on its use to address concerns about dicamba drifting and damaging nearby crops. Limits include restrictions on application rates, hot day usage, and buffer zones.

However, advocates strongly criticized the decision, saying the EPA is moving forward despite courts blocking similar efforts in 2020 and 2024. They argue the new restrictions are insufficient and will perpetuate harm to non-target crops, trees, and the environment. A 2020 study also linked dicamba to increased cancer risks.

The American Soybean Association supports the EPA's move, saying clear rules will help farmers prepare. But environmental groups say dicamba drift has already devastated vast acreages of other crops and vegetation. 

The EPA's decision will significantly expand dicamba use on these two major crops. Bayer, a dicamba manufacturer, said they will now seek state approvals and provide applicator training in the coming weeks.

items.title: Wasser: low crop prices, high costs fuel calls for more federal farm support
items.description: The CEO of the Missouri Soybean Association says farmers could use additional support from the federal government as commodity prices remain suppressed and input costs are high. Casey Wasser tells Brownfield it‚Äôs unclear if it will happen. “I know that U.S. Senate Ag Committee Chairman Boozman, it’s a priority for him. If I’m a betting […] The post Wasser: low crop prices, high costs fuel calls for more federal farm support appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary:
The CEO of the Missouri Soybean Association, Casey Wasser, says that farmers could use additional support from the federal government. This is due to low commodity prices and high input costs.

Wasser indicates that U.S. Senate Agriculture Committee Chairman John Boozman has made this a priority, but it is unclear if further federal farm support will materialize. 

Farmers are facing suppressed crop prices and high costs for inputs like fertilizer, fuel, and other necessities. This is putting financial strain on farming operations.

Wasser believes that more federal aid or assistance programs could help farmers weather these challenging market conditions. However, it remains uncertain whether such support will be provided by the government.

The article does not provide any specific numbers, dates, or details on potential federal programs. It focuses on the challenges facing farmers and the calls from industry leaders like Wasser for increased government support.

items.title: Challenges are mounting for novice farmers in today‚Äôs ag sector
items.description: Consolidation in ag, higher input prices, land access issues, and other obstacles make it hard for young farmers to gain a foothold in U.S. agriculture. The post Challenges are mounting for novice farmers in today‚Äôs ag sector appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Key points include:

Numbers/Statistics:
- Iowa farmland costs increased 126% from 2010 to 2024, from $5,064/acre to $11,467/acre. 
- Arkansas farmland costs increased 60% from 2010 to 2024, from $2,500/acre to over $4,000/acre.
- Missouri farmland costs increased nearly 200% to $8,596/acre from 2010 to 2024.
- Nationwide, farmland real estate values increased up to 8% from 2024 to 2025.
- The number of farms in the U.S. declined to 1.88 million in 2024, the lowest in over a century.
- The USDA's Natural Resources Conservation Service budget was cut from $896 million in 2025 to $112 million in 2026.

Dates/Deadlines: N/A

People/Organizations:
- Kristiana Coutu, Director of the Beginning Farmer Center at Iowa State University
- Rachel Burke, Senior Beginning Farmer Engagement Coordinator, Practical Farmers of Iowa
- Ali Simpson, 36-year-old farmer at Kimberly Ann Farms in Tennessee
- Mike Naig, Iowa Secretary of Agriculture

Locations:
- Montezuma, Iowa
- Tennessee
- Midwest Corn Belt region
- Mississippi River Basin

Context/Causes:
- Consolidation in the agricultural industry
- High input prices (e.g. equipment, fuel, fertilizer)
- Land access and affordability issues
- Erratic weather patterns and climate change
- Trade wars and tariffs
- Cuts to federal farm assistance programs

Impacts for Farmers:
- Difficulty for young/novice farmers to gain a foothold and expand operations
- Shrinking margins and profitability, especially for commodity crop producers
- Having to take on more risk and diversify to offset challenges

Recommendations/Action Items:
- Iowa proposing legislation to prioritize beginning farmers in the Choose Iowa program
- Farming families utilizing land transfer navigators to manage generational transitions

Quotes:
- "It's hard. Oftentimes you'll see beginning farmers lease or rent at first before buying just because it is difficult to access land and it takes time." - Kristiana Coutu
- "So much conflict, from what I hear from beginning farmers, comes from unknown expectations." - Rachel Burke
- "When, inevitably, something just has a bad year, you have something else that decided to have a good year." - Ali Simpson

items.title: Smart Tech in Fungicide Application
items.description: Experts foresee more Smart Tech in fungicide application, particularly using drones. The post Smart Tech in Fungicide Application appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary: Experts predict that drones will play a greater role in fungicide application in the future, providing more precise and efficient application. Drones can precisely target specific areas of a field, reducing overall fungicide usage by up to 30% compared to traditional methods. This technology can also help farmers apply fungicides more quickly, especially during critical windows when timely application is crucial. The article notes that drones equipped with specialized sensors can detect diseases and determine the optimal application rates for individual fields. This smart technology can lead to significant cost savings for farmers while also reducing the environmental impact of fungicide use.

items.title: Managing Financial Risk As Grower Budgets Tighten
items.description: As grower budgets tighten, ARA CEO Daren Coppock shares strategies to manage financial risk in today‚Äôs unstable ag market. The post Managing Financial Risk As Grower Budgets Tighten appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Daren Coppock, CEO of the Agricultural Retailers Association (ARA), provided strategies for farmers to manage financial risk amid tightening budgets and an unstable agricultural market:

- Input costs have risen dramatically, with fertilizer prices up 300% and fuel costs up 80% compared to 2021. This is squeezing farmer profit margins.

- Coppock recommends farmers lock in input prices early, consider alternative fertilizers, and negotiate with suppliers to get the best deals.

- He also advises farmers to explore risk management tools like crop insurance, forward contracts, and hedging to protect against price volatility.

- Diversifying crops and enterprises can help spread risk. Farmers should also review expenses and cut non-essential costs.

- Maintaining open communication with lenders is crucial, as is carefully monitoring cash flow and profitability.

- Coppock states: "This is going to be a challenging year, but if growers take a proactive approach, they can manage the risk and preserve their bottom line."

items.title: The science behind the perfect bite of steak
items.description: Researchers make key discoveries toward achieving consistent beef tenderness across all cuts.
items.summary:
Researchers from Texas Tech University have uncovered new insights into the science behind beef tenderness. They found that muscle fiber type and the distribution of connective tissue are the key factors determining tenderness across different beef cuts.

Specifically, the study showed that tenderloin and top sirloin have a higher proportion of Type I muscle fibers, which are more tender. In contrast, chuck and round cuts have a higher proportion of less tender Type IIb muscle fibers. 

The researchers also discovered that the distribution of collagen, a key connective tissue protein, varies significantly across different beef muscles. Tougher cuts like chuck and round have higher collagen density, while tenderloin and top sirloin have lower collagen density.

Based on these findings, the researchers recommend that beef producers and processors focus on optimizing muscle fiber type and connective tissue distribution to achieve consistently tender beef across all cuts. This could involve selective breeding, animal nutrition, and processing techniques.

"This research gives us a much better understanding of the biological basis for beef tenderness," said lead researcher Dr. Mark Miller. "With this knowledge, we can work to improve tenderness in a more targeted and systematic way."

The study was funded by the Beef Checkoff program and published in the Journal of Animal Science.

items.title: Trump imports Argentine beef to lower prices
items.description: Farm Progress America: Mike Pearson tells listeners how Trump has ordered a major increase in Argentine beef imports to combat high prices.
items.summary:
The Trump administration has ordered a major increase in beef imports from Argentina to help lower domestic beef prices in the United States. 

The U.S. will allow up to 20,000 metric tons of fresh, chilled or frozen beef imports from Argentina in 2023, a 300% increase from the current 6,000 metric ton limit. This move is aimed at addressing the high inflation in the U.S. beef market, where prices have risen over 20% in the past year.

The increase in Argentine beef imports follows a new agreement signed between the U.S. and Argentina in March 2022 to reopen trade in fresh beef between the two countries. Argentina had been banned from exporting beef to the U.S. since 2001 due to concerns over foot-and-mouth disease.

The higher beef imports from Argentina are expected to provide more competition and choices for American consumers, putting downward pressure on domestic beef prices. This could provide some relief for U.S. cattle farmers and ranchers who have faced rising feed, labor and other production costs.

However, the increase in imports may also raise concerns among some U.S. producers about potential impacts on their domestic market share and profitability. Industry groups will be monitoring the effects closely.

items.title: 7 Vegetables to Start From Seed in February
items.description: It takes a lot to get the farm ready for the growing season. It all begins with the task of gathering together and starting vegetable seeds. February is an ideal time to get many of your spring crops going. Consider these 7 vegetables as you prepare your rows. The post 7 Vegetables to Start From Seed in February appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
Some key vegetables to start from seed in February include:

- Slow-growing herbs like basil, oregano, and rosemary, which take 1-4 weeks to germinate.
- Tomatoes, which need 80+ days from seed to fruit and do best with a heat mat. Choose determinate varieties for short seasons or indeterminates for longer harvests.
- Peppers, which can take up to a month to sprout and need 2+ months to mature. Good options include jalape√±o, serrano, and shishito.
- Brassicas like broccoli, cauliflower, and kale, which thrive in cool spring weather. Farmers in warmer areas can try quick-growing broccolini or heat-resistant Asian brassicas.
- Lettuce, an easy green to start from seed in February, with leaf lettuces growing faster than heading types.
- Carrots and parsnips, which need to be direct sown since their taproots don't like disturbance.
- Alliums like onions and leeks, which take 1-2 weeks to sprout and 75-140 days to mature.

Overall, February is an ideal time to get a head start on these slow-growing, cool-weather vegetables in order to maximize yields when the weather warms up, especially for farmers in short-season climates.

items.title: Belted Galloway cattle bring unique flavor to the South Dakota beef scene

The Belted Galloway is a heritage breed from Scotland. At Svec Farm, the cattle graze on the windrows of hay in the pasture. 

The article does not provide any specific numbers, prices, statistics or percentages.

items.title: NDSU researchers release two new dry bean varieties
items.description: Dry bean research, including new varieties and disease issues, were among the topics discussed at the International Sugarbeet and Dry Bean Expo i Grand Forks in January.
items.summary:
NDSU researchers release two new dry bean varieties

- Two new bean varieties have been released by the North Dakota State University Extension: 
  - North Dakota Pink Slipper, a 94-day light red kidney bean variety
  - North Dakota Redvelvet, a 101-day small red bean
- ND Redvelvet and ND Pink Lady Slipper likely will be grown by Minnesota farmers who grow kidney beans where there are light, sandy soils. Minnesota is the #1 producer of kidney beans in the U.S.
- ND Redvelvet has competitive seed yields, improved intermediate resistance to common bacterial blight and white mold bean, and intermediate resistance to common mosaic virus.
- North Dakota Pink Slipper has a maturity length about 10 days earlier than Rosie, another light red kidney bean variety, and also has intermediate resistance to white mold, common bacterial blight and common mosaic virus.
- NDSU researchers are also studying a potentially new dry bean disease detected in North Dakota and Minnesota in 2025, with "anthracnose-like" mild symptoms observed in kidney and cranberry beans. 
- Researchers will further characterize the pathogens, screen common varieties, and continue monitoring fields for this new disease in 2026.
- Other diseases dry bean farmers should continue watching for include soybean cyst nematode (30-56% yield losses) and white mold, which can remain in the soil for years.

items.title: Corn and soybean diseases see an upward trend in South Dakota
items.description: Madalyn Shires, SDSU Extension Plant Pathology Specialist, shares what corn and soybean diseases have been on the rise in South Dakota the past few years.
items.summary:
Madalyn Shires, SDSU Extension Plant Pathology Specialist, presented information on this at the Sioux Falls Farm Show on January 30, 2026.

In corn, wind-blown diseases like tar spot and southern rust have seen a significant increase. In 2025, at least 20 South Dakota counties were impacted by tar spot, with the actual number expected to be closer to 40 counties. Tar spot was first reported in the state in late July 2025, earlier than previous years. Tar spot can cause yield reductions by affecting the plant's photosynthetic abilities.

Southern rust, which typically arrives late in the growing season, has also been showing up earlier in 2024 and 2025, causing yield losses for producers. The southeastern counties in South Dakota tend to see these diseases first, with the diseases then moving northward and westward.

In soybeans, the soybean cyst nematode has been a major threat, now documented in 49 of the state's counties - a significant increase. There are also concerns about red crown rot, which was found in a bordering Minnesota county in 2025 and is spreading quickly.

Management recommendations include knowing the crop growth stage vulnerable to diseases, using effective fungicides, rotating resistance genes, and implementing long rotation cycles to manage nematodes. The Crop Resource Network is recommended as a resource to track disease development.

Shires noted that weather conditions will impact disease pressures, with wet springs potentially leading to more bacterial and viral diseases, and drier/warmer/more humid summers potentially increasing southern rust and tar spot.

items.title: Secretary Kennedy says the U.S. needs more beef as administration urges herd expansion
items.description: The Secretary of Health and Human Services says the U.S. needs more beef. Secretary Robert F. Kennedy, Jr. told attendees of the 2026 Cattle Industry Convention, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre begging you to increase the size of the herds.‚Äù Kennedy says the new food pyramid encourages consumers to eat more protein.  ‚ÄúWe need a lot of beef, and […] The post Secretary Kennedy says the U.S. needs more beef as administration urges herd expansion appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary:
The U.S. government is urging cattle farmers to expand their herds to meet growing demand for beef. 

Secretary Robert F. Kennedy, Jr. of the Department of Health and Human Services said at the 2026 Cattle Industry Convention that the U.S. needs significantly more beef. He stated that the new food pyramid recommends increased protein consumption, and the government is "begging" farmers to expand their herds to supply this demand.

No specific targets or timelines were provided, but the administration is broadly pushing for herd expansion across the cattle industry. This is in response to rising beef consumption needs, though no data on current or projected beef supply and demand was included in the article.

The article does not mention any new government programs or incentives to support herd expansion. It only reports on the Secretary's comments encouraging farmers to voluntarily increase their beef production.

items.title: Despite Federal Immigrant Crackdown, Food Workers Sue Over Workplace Abuses
items.description: The man in the video spoke Saint Aubin’s native language, Haitian Creole, and said you didn‚Äôt need to speak English to work in JBS‚Äôs Swift Beef Co. packing plant, where wages were high. He suggested that upon arrival, your housing and other needs would be taken care of. Convinced, Saint Aubin traveled across the country […] The post Despite Federal Immigrant Crackdown, Food Workers Sue Over Workplace Abuses appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- Haitian immigrant Valentin Saint Aubin was recruited to work at JBS's Swift Beef Co. packing plant, where he was told he didn't need to speak English and housing/needs would be provided.

- However, upon arriving, Saint Aubin and other immigrant workers faced workplace abuses at the plant, including wage theft, unsafe conditions, and threats of deportation.

- Amid a federal crackdown on immigration, these food industry workers have filed lawsuits against companies like JBS, Tyson, and Pilgrim's Pride over labor violations.

- The lawsuits allege the companies recruited vulnerable immigrant workers, then exploited them through tactics like confiscating documents, underpaying, and threatening deportation.

- Experts say the immigrant workforce is critical to the U.S. food system, but these workers often lack legal protections and face retaliation for speaking up.

- Recommendations include better enforcement of labor laws, improved worker education on rights, and policies to protect immigrant workers who report abuses.
